content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSE. The "Compact-Impact Reimbursement Act" was created to address adverse consequences for Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and Hawaii resulting from the Compact of Free Association. Congress promised to act sympathetically and quickly to mitigate any negative effects caused by migration from the Freely Associated States. The Compact-Impact Reimbursement Act aims to address the budgetary strain on Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and Hawaii due to increased demands on health, education, and social services from migrants under the Compact of Free Association. The Compact-Impact Reimbursement Act aims to address the financial consequences of the Compact of Free Association by meeting obligations set forth in the Compact for the Republic of Palau. The Compact-Impact Reimbursement Act ensures mandatory appropriations and health services reimbursement as part of Compact-Impact aid. The Compact-Impact Reimbursement Act authorizes $35,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2023 for grants to Guam, Hawaii, Northern Mariana Islands, and American Samoa to cover increased costs in health, education, social, and public safety services. The Compact-Impact Reimbursement Act authorizes grants for health, education, social, and public safety services or infrastructure related to such services for qualified nonimmigrants. The grants are awarded and administered by the Department of the Interior, Office of Insular Affairs, and can only be used for specified purposes. The Secretary of the Interior conducts periodic enumerations of qualified nonimmigrants in Guam, Hawaii, the Northern Mariana Islands, and American Samoa every five years. The Secretary of the Interior conducts periodic enumerations of qualified nonimmigrants in Guam, Hawaii, the Northern Mariana Islands, and American Samoa every five years, beginning in fiscal year 2004. The allocations of grants to these governments are based on the number of qualified nonimmigrants. The Secretary of the Interior conducts periodic enumerations of qualified nonimmigrants in Guam, Hawaii, the Northern Mariana Islands, and American Samoa every five years, based on the number of qualified nonimmigrants. For medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act, qualified nonimmigrants in certain states or territories are treated similarly to individuals under Public Law 104-193, with the same Federal medical assistance percentage. The term 'qualified nonimmigrant' refers to individuals admitted to the US under specific agreements, with medical assistance payments not affecting limitations under the Social Security Act. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985, as amended, includes provisions for medical assistance effective from October 1, 2003, for individuals from Palau under specific agreements. SEC. 3. ENSURING FOOD STAMPS ELIGIBILITY AS PART OF COMPACT-IMPACT AID. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is further amended to address social impact costs in the food stamp program for qualified nonimmigrants. Sections 401(a) and 402(a)(1) of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 will not apply to these individuals. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is amended to exempt qualified nonimmigrants from certain sections of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 and the Food Stamp Act of 1977. This amendment will be effective from October 1, 2003. SEC. 4. Ensuring control and prevention of communicable diseases as part of Compact-Impact Aid. Section 105(o) of the Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is amended to authorize grants for communicable disease control programs in various regions, including cholera and Hansen's Disease. The Secretary of the Interior will assist in designing and implementing these programs. SEC. 5. Ensuring availability of Department of Defense medical facilities and National Health Service Corps services for Compact-Impact Aid. Section 105(k) of the Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is amended to make Department of Defense medical facilities available for individuals from Micronesia, Marshall Islands, and Palau. Defense facilities can be used by those properly referred by government authorities responsible for medical services in various regions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide National Health Service Corps services to residents of Micronesia, Marshall Islands, and Palau as authorized for individuals in the United States. SEC. 6. ENSURING RETIREMENT OF MEDICAL REFERRAL DEBTS AS PART OF COMPACT-IMPACT AID. Section 105(d) of the Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is amended to provide additional funds for the payment of medical facility obligations incurred by individuals from Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, and Palau before October 1, 2003. Amendments include striking certain language in paragraph (2) and (3) to clarify provisions.
